Clinical features: Most sandfly fever virus infections are thought to be subclinical as suggested by high seroprevalence rates in endemic regions, but with relatively few clinical cases.
39 Symptomatic infections are typically self-limited with fever, headache, muscle and joint pain, fatigue, and abdominal pain. Facial flushing and rapid heart rate can sometimes occur. However, Toscana virus can cause encephalitis, meningitis, and peripheral neuropathy. 35, 37 In most Toscana virusâ€“infected patients, fever, headache, nausea, and vomiting with nuchal rigidity occur, and depressed consciousness can be present in about 10% of cases. CSF shows mild pleocytosis with elevated protein and glucose levels, although protein and glucose may be normal. 37, 40, 41 In addition to Toscana virus, SFTV can cause severe disease, including rarely CNS infections. 33, 42, 43
